channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Japan Earthquake: Rescuers Search Rubble After Powerful Earthquake Strikes Japan
item.description: Officials ordered evacuations and said that some people could be trapped under collapsed buildings after a quake struck the western prefecture of Ishikawa.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Yusuke Fukuhara/Yomiuri Shimbun, via, Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Damage in Wajima City, Japan, after an earthquake on Monday.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: One Year On, Netanyahu’s Government Holds Together Amid Divisions
item.description: Despite plummeting popularity, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has made clear he has no intention of resigning after the war in Gaza ends.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel’s Iron Dome anti-missile system intercepting rockets launched from the Gaza Strip, as seen from Ashkelon, Israel, on Sunday night.

item.title: Putin Vows to Keep Up Bombardment After a Russian City Is Hit
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia says his country will continue targeting Ukrainian cities in retaliation for a deadly attack on the city of Belgorod on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media shows President Vladimir V. Putin meeting with service members on Monday outside Moscow.

item.title: Pope Raises Concerns About Church in Nicaragua
item.description: Speaking at his traditional New Year’s Day message, Francis highlighted the arrests and expulsion of clergy.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: During his New Year’s Day address, Pope Francis said he was “following with concern what is happening in Nicaragua” and its crackdown on the Catholic Church.

item.title: They Said ‘I Do’ in a Moscow Prison
item.description: She’s 18. He’s 23. He sent her a one-sentence letter through his prison’s electronic mail system: “Will you marry me?” They wed in a small room in a Moscow jail.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Yegor Shtovba, right at rear, and a fellow defendant, Artyom Kamardin, at a Moscow court in December, with guards in the foreground.

item.title: Powerful Earthquake Hits Japan, and Officials Warn of Aftershocks
item.description: There were reports of collapsed buildings and people being trapped underneath them. The quake disrupted electricity and phone service, and initially raised fears of a tsunami.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Collapsed road and houses because of an earthquake in Wajima, Ishikawa prefecture, Japan, on Monday.

item.title: How to Start the New Year? Keep the Sea Goddess Happy.
item.description: Followers of Afro-Brazilian religions have been displaced by New Year’s revelers. But they still find ways to make their offerings to the ocean.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Dado Galdieri
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carrying offerings to the sea on Friday in Rio de Janeiro as part of an annual rite by devotees of Afro-Brazilian religions.

item.title: Half of Gazans Are at Risk of Starving, U.N. Warns
item.description: More than 90 percent of Palestinians in the territory say they have regularly gone without food for a whole day, according to the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Gaya Gupta and Abu Bakr Bashir
item.media:description: Palestinians crowded in to get a free meal in the city of Rafah in southern Gaza last month.

item.title: Israel Plans to Withdraw Some Troops From Gaza
item.description: Analysts say the announcement could signal a shift to the more limited and targeted war against Hamas that the United States has been urging.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Isabel Kershner and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers returning to their home soil from deployment in Gaza on Sunday.

item.title: At These Schools, Arab and Jewish Students Share Their Feelings, With Each Other
item.description: At a time when support for peace is at a low, conversations at Israel’s Hand in Hand schools about the Oct. 7 attack and the war in Gaza sound different than they do elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Haya Saleh, a Palestinian citizen of Israel, with students this month at the Max Rayne Hand in Hand school in Jerusalem. She teaches a class on tolerance and empathy with a Jewish Israeli teacher.

item.title: Inmates of Chile’s Largest Prison Find Solace in Caring for Stray Cats
item.description: In Chile’s oldest and most overcrowded prison, the inmates have found solace in the hundreds of stray cats.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Cristobal Olivares for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cat on a prisoner’s back in Chile’s Santiago Sur prison.

item.title: Burundi’s President Says Gay People Should Be Stoned
item.description: President Evariste Ndayishimiye also railed against Western governments that he said had conditioned providing aid on accepting gay rights. His remarks do not carry the force of law.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: President Evariste Ndayishimiye of Burundi has called on citizens to stone gay people.

item.title: Congo’s President Declared Victor in Election Marred by Delays and Protests
item.description: The Central African nation’s vote drew accusations of fraud, but the elections commissioner declared that the incumbent, Felix Tshisekedi, had won.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Supporters of Felix Tshisekedi, who was declared the winner of the presidential election, in Gombe, Kinshasa, on Sunday.

item.title: The World in Stories: 13 Favorite Dispatches From 2023
item.description: Our correspondents ventured to some of the world’s most remote, and dangerous, locales to report stories that reveal a country’s culture and the human condition. Here are our favorites from the year.
item.dc:creator: Bryant Rousseau

item.title: Israel’s Supreme Court Strikes Down Judiciary Law
item.description: The Supreme Court, by the narrowest of margins, rejected a law pushed by Netanyahu allies that limited its authority to review government decisions.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Israelis watching a broadcast of the Supreme Court considering a challenge in September to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s judicial overhaul.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel’s Top Court Rejects Move to Limit It
item.description: Plus New Year’s offerings to the sea in Brazil.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: People took part in a demonstration against Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his nationalist coalition government’s judicial overhaul in Tel Aviv in September.

item.title: Fukushima Disaster Still Looms Large in Japan Years After Quake
item.description: As another major quake struck Japan, the country was still reckoning with the nuclear crisis triggered by the 8.9-magnitude earthquake and a tsunami of 13 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evacuees at a temporary shelter in Fukushima, Japan, in March 2011.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Friction between the U.S. and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: U.S. Helicopters Sink 3 Houthi Boats in Red Sea, Pentagon Says
item.description: Iranian-backed Houthi gunmen from Yemen had fired on American helicopters responding to an attack on a commercial ship, American officials said.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Vivek Shankar
item.media:description: Looking out at the U.S.S. Eisenhower in the Persian Gulf in November. Helicopters from the aircraft carrier came under fire from the Houthis on Sunday.

item.title: Asian American Officials Cite Unfair Scrutiny and Lost Jobs in China Spy Tensions
item.description: National security employees with ties to Asia say U.S. counterintelligence officers wrongly regard them as potential spies and ban them from jobs.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I know dozens of diplomats who have lost out on getting assignments to China, Hong Kong and Vietnam,” said Yuki Kondo-Shah, a diplomat in London who successfully fought an assignment restriction placed on her for Japan.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Ukraine Steps Up Sabotage
item.description: Plus the beloved cats of a Chilean prison.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Investigative Committee of Russia, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo Russia released last month purporting to show the site of a derailed train.

item.title: Queen Margrethe II of Denmark Announces Abdication of Throne After 52 Years
item.description: Margrethe, the longest-serving monarch in Europe, announced during her New Year’s speech that she would abdicate her throne in January. Her eldest son, Crown Prince Frederik, will succeed her.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Nielsen and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Margrethe II of Denmark at Christiansborg Castle in Copenhagen last month.

item.title: Putin and Zelensky Address Their Citizens on New Year’s Eve
item.description: The message of resilience offered by Ukraine’s leader, Volodymyr Zelensky’s message, contrasted sharply with that of President Vladimir V. Putin, who glossed over the war in an effort to project a sense of normality.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine Intensifies Guerrilla Tactics, Targeting Trains
item.description: As conventional forces struggle to break through defensive lines, both sides are increasingly turning to guerrilla tactics.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Investigative Committee of Russia, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo Russia released last month purporting to show the site of a derailed train in the Ryazan region, Russia. Russian authorities said the derailment was caused by an improvised explosive device.

item.title: Defying U.S. Pressure, Israel Deepens Gaza Assault
item.description: Under the withering attacks, 165 people were killed in the past 24 hours, Gazan officials said, while Israel said it had destroyed the apartment of a Hamas leader.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Roni Caryn Rabin and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Smoke billowing over Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Saturday.

item.title: Conflict in Israel and Gaza, in Photos
item.description: A surprise attack by Hamas put Israel and the group that controlled Gaza at war. Here are images from the assault and what has followed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescuers struggling to remove an injured woman from under the rubble of a building hit by an Israeli strike on Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Dec. 28.

item.title: Mia Schem, an Israeli Hostage, Shares Harrowing Details of Gaza Captivity
item.description: An account of being held for 55 days in Gaza has touched a particular nerve in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:description: Keren Scharf Schem holding a portrait of her daughter, Mia Schem, who was released in November after being held captive by Hamas for 55 days.

item.title: Ukrainian Missile Attack on Belgorod Kills at Least 18, Officials Say
item.description: The bombardment of Belgorod on Saturday, apparently in response to an enormous air assault by Moscow a day earlier, appeared to be the deadliest single attack on Russian soil since the start of the war.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Ivan Nechepurenko

item.title: How a Russian Barrage Evaded Ukraine’s Defenses to Wreak Deadly Chaos
item.description: In one of the war’s largest bombardments, 35 missiles slipped through Ukraine’s air cover on Friday, killing dozens. Ukraine responded with shelling on the Russian region of Belgorod, killing at least 22.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Stretcher-bearers with a victim of a Russian missile strike in Zaporizhzhia, in southern Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Biden Administration Again Bypasses Congress for Weapons Sale to Israel
item.description: The move comes as Israel presses on with its offensive in Gaza despite increasing pressure from the United States to lower the conflict’s intensity.
item.dc:creator: Matt Surman and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers firing 155-millimeter artillery shells near the Gaza border in November.

item.title: Words of Wisdom
item.description: Readers share the best advice they received this year.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canada Letter: Restaurants That Are Local Institutions, According to Readers
item.description: We asked Canada Letter readers to tell us about the restaurants that have become institutions in their communities.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Les Fougères opened 30 years ago in Chelsea, Quebec.

item.title: Italy’s Raucous Holiday Classics Are Not Your Standard Hallmark Movies
item.description: Gleefully vulgar, the genre known as “Cinepanettone” once dominated Italy over the holidays. Italian revelers recently flocked to the alpine town where many of the films were set.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Chiara Negrello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerry Calà, who played a piano bar singer in the 1983 Italian comedy “Christmas Holiday,” during a celebration this month in Cortina, Italy.

item.title: As War Rages in Ukraine, Denmark Turns an Office Park Back Into an Arsenal
item.description: The conflict and surging arms production in Russia have spurred demand for ammunition manufacturing across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firing a 155-millimeter howitzer in the Donetsk region of Ukraine. A widely promoted E.U. campaign to provide one million 155-millimeter rounds to Ukraine within 12 months is expected to fail.

item.title: How Greggs, a Super Affordable Bakery Chain, Became a U.K. Culinary Icon
item.description: A festive pop-up restaurant is the latest crowd-pleasing stunt from Greggs, a mass-market bakery that is riding out Britain’s cost-of-living crisis with gusto.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: This week in Newcastle, England, where Greggs bakery was founded in 1939.

item.title: Where Was the Israeli Military When Hamas Attacked?
item.description: A Times investigation found that troops were disorganized, out of position and relied on social media to choose targets. Behind the failure: Israel had no battle plan for a massive Hamas invasion.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman, Ronen Bergman, Mark Mazzetti, Natan Odenheimer, Alexander Cardia, Ainara Tiefenthäler and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: Hamas teams breached the Israel-Gaza border fence in dozens of locations.

item.title: Palestinians in Southern Gaza Face Dangers Where They Seek Shelter
item.description: Many residents feel that no place is safe after an airstrike in an area of southern Gaza where Israel had ordered people to seek shelter.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Thomas Fuller
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: An airstrike by the Israeli military in an area designated as a safe zone killed 18 people in the southern Gaza city of Rafah on Friday, Palestinian health officials said.

item.title: South Africa Accuses Israel of Genocide in U.N. Court
item.description: Israel’s Foreign Ministry said the filing was a “despicable and contemptuous exploitation of the court.”
item.dc:creator: Traci Carl
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa has compared Israel’s treatment of Palestinians to apartheid, the racist system of segregation that governed South Africans for nearly 50 years before it ended in 1994.

item.title: Israeli Military Releases New Details on Killing of 3 Hostages
item.description: In the latest disclosure on the shooting by Israeli soldiers of three hostages, the military said 15 minutes elapsed between the killing of the first two and the third.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of Alon Shamriz, one of the hostages mistakenly killed by Israeli soldiers in the Gaza Strip, in Shefayim earlier this month.

item.title: U.N. Says Israeli Forces Fired on Aid Convoy in Central Gaza
item.description: The convoy, whose vehicles were marked with U.N. insignia, was returning from delivering aid, including flour. No one was injured.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: An aid convoy waiting to head toward northern Gaza last month.

item.title: China Appoints Adm. Dong Jun as Defense Minister
item.description: The promotion of Adm. Dong Jun may calm uncertainty after the unexplained disappearance of the previous minister, Gen. Li Shangfu.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: China on Friday appointed Adm. Dong Jun as defense minister.

item.title: Russia Sends Navalny Associate to Prison for ‘Extremism’
item.description: The nine-year sentence reflects how the Kremlin continues to crack down on Aleksei A. Navalny’s political movement years after his organization was banned.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Ksenia V. Fadeyeva, the coordinator of Aleksei A. Navalny’s political office in the Siberian city of Tomsk, in 2020 with a poster promoting her candidacy for municipal parliament.

item.title: The Year in People: Our 12 Favorite Saturday Profiles of 2023
item.description: From a Nobel Peace Prize winner, to a mayor hunted by the Russians, to a poet whose muses are cats, our profiles featured people shaping the world around them, often under the radar.
item.dc:creator: Bryant Rousseau
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Nina Riggio for NYT; Alexia Webster for NYT; Laura Boushnak for NYT; Jun Michael Park for NYT; Noriko Hayashi for NYT; Daniele Volpe for NYT
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Johannes Fritz, an Austrian biologist; Nomcebo Zikode, a South African singer; Moha Alshawamreh, a Palestinian tech worker; Hwang In-suk, a South Korean poet; Shinjiro Atae, a J-pop idol; and María Mercedes Coroy, a Guatemalan actress.

item.title: At Least 30 Killed in Ukraine After Russian Missile Attacks
item.description: The missile and drone attacks killed at least 30 people and damaged critical industrial and military infrastructure, part of a wintertime campaign that Ukraine had been dreading.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk
item.media:description: Smoke rising after a strike in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Deadly Plane Crash in Nepal Caused by Pilot Error, Report Finds
item.description: One pilot changed the propeller angle instead of that of the wing flaps while trying to land a Yeti Airlines plane in January, a report said.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and John Yoon
item.media:description: Rescue teams working at the crash site of the Yeti Airlines aircraft in Pokhara, Nepal, in January.

item.title: In U.K. Town, a New Way of Caring for Older People
item.description: An “integrated care center” brings doctors, physiotherapists, social workers and pharmacists under one roof. It won’t solve Britain’s underlying social care crisis — but it could help.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vanessa Joyce, 67, had her blood pressure taken and her heart rate checked at her home by an advanced community nurse practitioner, Samantha Hines, from the Jean Bishop Integrated Care Centre, in Hull, in June.

item.title: Hong Kong Activist Flees to UK, Citing Police Pressure
item.description: The activist, Tony Chung, was imprisoned after advocating for the territory’s independence. Even after his release, he said, his situation remained oppressive.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Tony Chung in Hong Kong in August 2020.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Hamas’s campaign of sexual violence.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gal Abdush’s parents, center, and her sisters. The photograph on the wall shows Gal and her husband, Nagi. The couple had been together since they were teenagers.

item.title: How Life at Sea’s 3-Year Cruise Unraveled
item.description: The Life at Sea cruise was supposed to be the ultimate bucket-list experience: 382 port calls worldwide over 1,095 days. The only thing missing was a trip-worthy ship.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:credit: Rena R. Effendi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joe Youssef and his wife, Kara, sold most of their belongings and withdrew their savings to join a three-year cruise that never sailed. “We sold everything we have to make this dream happen,” Ms. Youssef said. “We feel completely defeated.”

item.title: Israel Expresses Regret for Civilian Casualties in Gaza Airstrike
item.description: The Israeli military said it was “working to draw lessons” from an attack in central Gaza that was reported to have killed dozens of people.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Isabel Kershner and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Palestinians mourning their relatives, killed in an overnight Israeli strike on the Al-Maghazi refugee camp, during a mass funeral at Al-Aqsa Hospital in Deir Al-Balah, in the central Gaza Strip, on Monday.

item.title: Israeli American Thought to Be a Hamas Hostage Was Killed on Oct. 7, Family Says
item.description: The bodies of Judih Weinstein Haggai and her husband, Gadi Haggai, are still held by Hamas, their family said.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Iris Weinstein Haggai, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gadi Haggai and his wife, Judih Weinstein Haggai, in an undated photograph. They were shot and killed during the Oct. 7 attacks on Kibbutz Nir Oz, their family said on Thursday.

item.title: ‘Almost Naked’ Party in Moscow Angers Russian Conservatives
item.description: Outrage over scantily clad socialites highlights the growing contradictions of a society reshaped by the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: People attending an erotic celebrity party organized by a Russian influencer, Anastasia Ivleyeva, at a Moscow nightclub.

item.title: Friday Briefing: A Pattern of Rape and Torture on Oct. 7
item.description: Also, migration to the U.S. and the threat to art from A.I.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Boeing Urges Airlines to Inspect 737 Max Planes for Possible Loose Bolts
item.description: The F.A.A. said it was monitoring inspections after an airline discovered a bolt with a missing nut in the plane’s rudder-control system.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:description: Boeing said it has delivered more than 1,370 of the aircraft, and was urging that all of them be inspected for the possible loose hardware.

item.title: Chess Federation Fines Player Over Her ‘Sports Shoes’
item.description: The Dutch chess player, who received an official warning, said she did not intend to violate the dress code when she wore her canvas Burberry sneakers at a chess championship in Uzbekistan.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Anna-Maja Kazarian said that leaving the venue of the World Rapid and Blitz Championships in Samarkand, Uzbekistan, to change her shoes made her feel stressed and unfocused during Thursday’s rounds.

item.title: 2023 Obituaries: A Host of Consequential, and Very Long, Lives Lost
item.description: Life expectancy averages may be falling, but you might not have been able to tell that from reading the obituaries about many luminaries this year.
item.dc:creator: William McDonald
item.media:credit: Frans Schellekens/Redferns; Donal F. Holway, via The New York Times; Neil Leifer, via Sports Illustrated, via Getty Images; Corbis, via Getty Images; Bob Henriques, via Magnum Photos; Emilio Morenatti, via Associated Press; Celeste Sloman for The New York Times; Phil Ramey, via Associated Press; Matt York, via Associated Press; Tony Tomsic, via Associated Press; Chester Higgins Jr., via The New York Times; Paolo Pellegrin, via Magnum Photos; MGM; Adrian Dennis, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Top row, from left: Sinead O’Connor, Daniel Ellsberg, Henry Kissinger, Rosalynn Carter, Harry Belafonte. Middle row, from left: Pervez Musharraf, Dianne Feinstein, Tina Turner, Sandra Day O’Connor. Bottom row, from left: Tony Bennett, Silvio Berlusconi, Glenda Jackson, Tori Bowie and Jim Brown.

item.title: How Hamas Weaponized Sexual Violence on Oct. 7
item.description: A Times investigation uncovered new details showing a pattern of rape, mutilation and extreme brutality against women in the attacks on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Anat Schwartz, Adam Sella and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Significant Damage’ Reported As Storm Gerrit Moves Through Britain
item.description: Strong winds and heavy rain are expected in England over the coming days, according to forecasters.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Strong winds damaged buildings near Manchester, England, this week.
